Description: Body sherd (mended from two fragments) of a large Attic black-figured pottery Nikosthenic pyxis; lower body offset; interior: glazed black with added red band; exterior: from top, black-figure decoration consisting of frontal chariot with charioteer, wearing added white robe, in chariot box (part of three horses with incised herring-bone pattern on tails; added red on horse’s mane and collar, front of chariot; white triple pendant dots at lower edge of horse’s collar); below moulded ridge, on the cul, lion (neck and part of head remaining; red mane and mouth; white teeth), to left, attacking an animal, probably a bull (trace remaining beside lion’s eye at left).
Curator's comments: For a frontal chariot of the same period, compare Oxford AN1885.665, a neck-amphora by the Lysippides Painter (CVA Oxford 2, pl. 5, pl. 7 and pl. 10, no. 4; ABV, 256, no. 15). For the lion attacking an animal, compare the column krater British Museum 1851,0416.6. 1886,0401.1187 may br from the lid belonging with this piece.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.19)
Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 265, no. 44)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 286-7, no. B259)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 235, no. 6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0821) (Phase 1)
Lyon 2009 / Nikosthenic Pyxides between Etruria and Greece (p. 26, p. 176, no. 26)
Condition: the lower part of the left break has a series of very shallow bore holes and traces of glue
